awd_titl_txt: GEM:   Mode Conversion and Kinetic Alfven Waves at the Magnetopause and Their Effects in the Magnetosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The transport of mass and momentum into the magnetosphere from the solar wind remains an important but incompletely understood problem.  This proposal will study wave-induced particle diffusive processes as a transport mechanism at the dayside magnetopause. In particular the team will investigate the processes involved in the conversion of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) fast mode waves to kinetic Alfven waves (KAWs).  The conversion to KAWs may be an effective mechanism for transport.  The processes involved here may be very important in laboratory and astrophysical plasmas as well as at the magnetopause. This research has an important element of basic plasma physics research.

The approach will be to use hybrid simulations (kinetic ions and fluid electrons in self-consistent electromagnetic fields) to investigate mode conversion in a local boundary layer. The team will investigate 1) the 3-D nonlinear physics of mode conversion, 2) the physics of mode conversion due to self-consistently generated foreshock compressional waves, 3) the observed signatures of mode conversion and the dependence of mode conversion on interplanetary magnetic field ( IMF)  and solar wind conditions, 4) the differences between KAWs due to mode conversion and those due to reconnection and 5) the impact of KAWs on the ionosphere through Poynting fluxes and field aligned currents. Comparison will be made between the simulation results and THEMIS observations in the magnetosphere and DMSP observations in the ionosphere.

The research will support a graduate student.

por.por_cntn:
We carried out a systematic investigation on the fundamental physics of the generation and dynamics of kinetic Alfven waves (KAWs) in the Earth’s magnetosphere in the self-consistent solar wind-magnetosphere interaction, by mode conversion and magnetic reconnection processes. The main methodology is through three-dimensional (3-D) global hybrid simulations of the magnetosphere under various interplanetary magnetic field and solar wind conditions. The hybrid model solves fully kinetic equations governing the ions and a fluid model for electrons in a self-consistent electromagnetic field. The major outcomes include the understanding of (1) where and how the KAWs are generated by interaction between the foreshock waves of the bow shock and the magnetopause, (2) the physics of ion cross field line and thermal diffusion in Alfvenic turbulence, (3) nonlinear instabilities associated with KAWs, and (4) generation of shear Alfven waves/KAWs by magnetic reconnection.

Four slides showing the intellectual merit of these major outcomes are attached.

Three Ph.D. graduate students have participated in the project as part of their Ph.D. thesis work. Through the project, these students have learned the techniques of hybrid simulation, physics of nonlinear waves and wave-particle interaction in a complex plasma system, and techniques of simulation data analysis/visualization. This training has greatly helped the students for their future professional career.

Our numerical simulations for the multi-scale, multi-dimensional magnetosphere have a direct impact to understanding of complex plasma systems in space and laboratory plasmas. The development of the Auburn global hybrid code in 3-D (ANGIE3D) has broader impacts to kinetic global modeling of plasmas in the realistic space environment and laboratory devices. The simulation will help us to distinguish the spatial and temporal effects in satellite observations and provide insight to the laboratory measurements.
